Title: Villa-Lobos: 12 Études For Guitar, W235 , Sheet Music Library (PDF)
Description: Villa-Lobos (Rio de Janeiro, March 5, 1887, November 17, 1959) was a Brazilian conductor and composer . His music was influenced by both Brazilian folk music and classical music . He also had a second career as a pedagogue of the music of his country .  Heitor Villa-Lobos was a notoriously prolific composer . His music for guitar can be cited as the Preludes (particularly famous No. 1, subtitled ‘Melodía lírica’ and composed in 1940), the Estudios and the Choros . Among the most popular works are the Bachianas brasileiras .  There is a room named in its honor in the National Theater of Brasilia and, among other tributes in streets and squares throughout Brazil, there is also the Villa-Lobos Park in São Paulo .

Description: Brazilian born guitar player Baden Powell has been one of the key musicians among his country’s jazz scene . Powell built his reputation as an innovator of bossa nova or the marriage of Brazilian sambas and jazz . His work demonstrates a mastery of many classical guitar styles .  Baden Powell is credited with defining what bossa nova meant to the world in the 1960s . Powell and Vinicius de Moraes were Brazil’s foremost poet . Powell was celebrated even more in Europe, where the cool jazz flavor of boss nova raged in many clubs . Powell moved to Europe in 1963, which remained his base of operations .

Title: Miles Davis - "So What" – The Top 25 Icons In Jazz History , Sheet Music Library (PDF)
Description: Jazz aficionados and musicians alike often debate the level of influence of one or another jazz artist on the genre as a whole . Miles Davis is the only predominantly jazz artist to be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame explicitly for his direct contribution to rock and roll . Davis' best and most influential recording, his 1959 record, Kind of Blue, is one of its signature tracks .  Miles Davis’ Kind of Blue is considered the “best-selling jazz record of all time” (Rolling Stone) The success of the record can be attributed to Davis' productive creativity which extended beyond his musical compositions and his understated elegance on the trumpet . Another of Davis' works that spawned several successful careers is his 1970 record, Bitches Brew .  Bitches Brew (Rolf and Watts) was released in 1968 . It was certified platinum (1 million copies sold) by the Recording Industry Association of America in 2003 (RIAA) Many credit the album with a resurgence in jazz popularity and commercial sales throughout the ‘70s .  Armstrong’s music in the 1920s, in particular on his Hot Five and Hot Seven recordings from 1925-1929, is considered by some to be “the most exciting and influential in jazz music” Armstrong continued to play jazz trumpet with masterful skill after the ‘20s, he turned his productive efforts to being a singer and entertainer .  Miles Davis influenced, innovated, and instigated multiple styles of jazz during his lifetime . Davis was consistently branching jazz in directions it had not yet traveled . Davis credited other musicians for their contributions .  Miles Dewey Davis III, a great trumpeter and composer, was one of the major influences on the art from the late 1940s . His unique, intimate tone and his fertile musical imagination outweighed his technical shortcomings . He formed classic small groups in the 1950s that featured saxophonelegends John Coltrane and Cannonball Adderley, pianists Red Garland and Bill Evans .  Kind of Blue includes the finest recorded examples of modal jazz, a style in which improvisations are based upon sparse chords and nonstandard scales rather than on complex, frequently changing chords . The early 1960s were transitional, less-innovative years for Davis, although his music and his playing remained top-calibre .  The Davis quintet’s experimentations in polyrhythm and polytonality were more subtle but equally daring . Bitches Brew (1969), an album on which he fully embraced the rhythms, electronic instrumentation, and studio effects of rock music . The album's influence was heard in such 1970s fusion groups as Weather Report .

Title: Beethoven Symphony No 9 In D Minor (with Score) , Sheet Music Library (PDF)
Description: Beethoven’s Symphony No. 9 premiered on May 7, 1824, in Vienna, to an overwhelmingly enthusiastic audience . The work represents an important stylistic bridge between Classical and Romantic periods of Western music history .  Beethoven’s Symphony No. 9 foreshadowed the monolithic works of Gustav Mahler, Richard Wagner, and other composers of the later Romantic era . The inclusion of a chorus in a genre that was understood to be exclusively instrumental was thoroughly unorthodox . The symphony's menacing second movement in brisk waltz time provided a backdrop for some of the most tense and twisted moments in Stanley Kubrick's 1971 film adaptation of A Clockwork Orange . Title: Brahms: Piano Sonatas (complete) , Sheet Music Library (PDF)
Description: Johannes Brahms composed for symphony orchestra, chamber ensembles, piano, organ, organ and voice and chorus . He is sometimes grouped with Johann Sebastian Bach and Ludwig van Beethoven as one of the “Three Bs” of music .  The diligent, highly constructed nature of Brahms’s works was a starting point and inspiration for a generation of composers . Embedded within his meticulous structures, however, are deeply romantic motifs . He wrote a number of major works for orchestra, including two Serenades, four symphonies, two piano concertos (No. 1 in D minor; No. 2 in B-flat major) and two companion orchestral overtures .  Brahms was an influence on composers of both conservative and modernist tendencies . His idiom left an imprint on several composers within his personal circle, such as Heinrich von Herzogenberg, Robert Fuchs, and Julius Röntgen .  Anton Webern claimed Brahms had anticipated developments of the Second Viennese School . Ann Scott has shown how Brahms anticipated the procedures of serialists by redistributing melodic fragments between instruments .

Title: Rachmaninoff - Symphony No. 2 In E Minor, Op. 27 3rd Mov. Adagio (Advanced Piano Solo) & Sheet Music , Sheet Music Library (PDF)
Description: Sergei Vasilyevich Rachmaninoff was a Russian composer, virtuoso pianist, and conductor of the late Romantic period . Influenced by Tchaikovsky, Rimsky-Korsakov, Balakirev, Mussorgsky and other Russian composers .  Rachmaninoff composed three one-act operas: Aleko (1892), The Miserly Knight (1903), and Francesca da Rimini (1904) He also composed many songs for voice and piano, to texts by A. N. Tolstoy, Pushkin, Goethe, Shelley and Chekhov .  Rachmaninoff’s compositional style had already begun changing before the October Revolution deprived him of his homeland . He started leaning towards sumptuous harmonies and broadly lyrical, often passionate melodies . His orchestration became subtler and more varied, with textures carefully contrasted .  Rachmaninoff ranked among the finest pianists of his time, along with Leopold Godowsky, Ignaz Friedman, Moriz Rosenthal, Josef Lhévinne, Ferruccio Busoni and Josef Hofmann .  Rachmaninoff's playing was marked by precision, rhythmic drive, notable use of staccato and ability to maintain clarity when playing works with complex textures . He may have based his interpretation of the Chopin sonata on that of Anton Rubinstein .  The Creative Development of Johann Sebastian Bach (1695-1717) Vol.  I and II is published in Bach’s first edition of The Bach Collection .

Title: Keith Jarrett Solo Tribute FULL CONCERT (1987) , Sheet Music Library (PDF)
Description: Keith Jarrett performs some of his most memorable and haunting standards before an enthusiastic crowd . Performed entirely solo, these numbers clearly reveal the breadth and power of his immense musical skills . Jarrett was born in Allentown, Pennsylvania, in May 1945 .  In the early 1980s Jarrett formed his “Standards Trio” with bassist Gary Peacock and drummer Jack DeJohnette . The American Quartet extended the range of Jarrrett’s trio with Charlie Haden and Paul Motian . In 1987, Jarrett initiated a series of recordings of some of the great monuments of the classical keyboard repertoire .

tweet:
I wrote a bit about a Ramones song that led me to their music. This was released 45 years ago in the UK, and OnThisDay it was no. 22 on the charts.
, Sheena_Is_a_Punk_Rocker 
Music Archive, Part XVIII ~ Ramones: Sheena Is a Punk Rocker https://t.co/dW2LruIcE1
Title: Music Archive, Part XVIII ~ Ramones: Sheena Is a Punk Rocker – Tales From The Brazier's Grotto
Description: Music Archive is a series, where I write about albums or singles that have been released years ago . This time I am not writing about an album, but about a song . The song is ‘Sheena Is a Punk Rocker’ by Ramones . This song was also released as a single, but I am only interested in the song that was on the A-side of that single .  The name of the heroine of the song comes from a comic-book character, Sheena, Queen of the Jungle . The looks for Sheena are taken directly from the comic-books; she is shown sitting on a tree branch, dressed in a leopard skin dress with a knife tied around her waist and holding a spear .  Katriina Etholén has always liked Ramones since she was a teenager . The band played twice at the Nummirock music festival in 1992 and 1994 .

tweet: Beethoven - Piano Sonata No 17 in D minor op 31 2 "Tempest" performed and commented by Glenn Gould , Sheet Music Library (PDF) https://t.co/lVTr0e5lCf
Title: Beethoven - Piano Sonata No 17 In D Minor Op 31 2 "Tempest" Performed And Commented By Glenn Gould , Sheet Music Library (PDF)
Description: The Piano Sonata No. 17 in D minor, Op.  31, No. 2, was composed in 1801–02 by Ludwig van Beethoven . It is usually referred to as The Tempest (or Der Sturm in his native German), but the sonata was not given this title .  Op.  2 sonata “the most dramatic that Beethoven had yet conceived, with a contrast of tempos and motifs, and a radical opposition of mood . “The opening motif…is a motto and it will govern the entire work” “This opening is constructed in a set of antecedent/consequent phrases.”  In the first movement of Op.  31, no. 2, the bass rises gradually over 20 bars (98-118) as the development section gets underway . An implied augmented sixth chord based on Bb propels the piece into a 12-bar prolongation of the A major dominant in fortissimo (bars 121- 132) Then a 5 – 4 – 3 – 2 – 1 melodic descent (for A major) in whole notes, with an A pedal in the bass, brings us to bar 137, where we get a hint of the recapitulation .  Op. 31 No. 2 is a redefinition of sonata form in terms of a transformational process, rather than a neatly divisible form . At the outset of the piece, the rolled/arpeggiated A major chord in the first two bars appears to be more like introductory material that precedes the main theme . Bar 1 first presents itself as a prelude lacking in thematic significance, later (when viewed in retrospect from bar 21) as the anticipation of the theme and finally (after it has emerged that bars 21-40 are a modulating developmental passage) as  The listener thus “follows the process of transformation” in which the motives/themes fulfill several functions at a time and the processual aspect of structure coexists with, if not supersedes, the theoretical divisions of sonata form . While the motivic relationships and their transformations are probably the clearest within the first movement, there are notable connections between the movements as well .  The opening thematic statement is richer in what it implies, than what it actually contains . The second movement is cast in the most traditional form of the three movements . The third movement starts with a clear tonic D in the bass, the pedal A in the tenor voice .  Op. 31 No. 2 is his first attempt at such a technique and represents a very important innovation . The first theme material does appear almost verbatim and the choice of the key to which Beethoven transposes it here (bar 150) – B flat minor– is quite intriguing .  The sonata Op. 27, no. 1 is one of the set of two sonatas subtitled by Beethoven “Quasi una fantasia’s “Moonlight” sonata . Op. 31 No. 1 (written 1800-1801) goes from Eb (movement 1 – Andante) to C minor . The first 6 bars of the third movement are largely cut and pasted before the coda in the fourth movement .  The Op. 20’s sonatas confirm that for Beethoven the piano sonataas were a field of experimentation”. “The Op. 27, no.  2 and Op. 28” were a one-key for the entire work, with C# minor (Adagio sostenuto) – Db (Allegretto) – C# major(Presto agitato) in Op.  28 .  Op. 31, no. 2 sonata may be seen as continuing a crystallization of thoughts that Beethoven had been exploring for some time’s personal crisis associated with his hearing loss . Many techniques were already used or toyed with in previous works .  The Creative Development of Johann Sebastian Bach (1695-1717) Vol.  I and II is published by Indiana University Press. It is titled Masters of the Keyboard: Individual Style Elements in the PIano Music of Bach .

tweet: The sound of a black hole https://t.co/6Hbb7SXiPw
Title: NASA releases audio recording of a black hole [Listen]
Description: NASA releases the sound recording of a black hole: Listeners can hear it by scaling up by 57 and 58 octaves above its recorded sound . The sound is taken from deep inside the Perseus Cluster, a collection of galaxies with a recession speed of 5,366 km/s and a diameter of 863′, it is one of the most significant objects in the universe .
